Review
Biochar-supported nanomaterials for environmental applications
Oscar M. Rodriguez-Narvaeza, Juan Manuel Peralta-Hernandeza, Ashantha Goonetillekeb, Erick R. Bandalac,d,* aDepartamento de Química, División de Ciencias Naturales y Exactas, Campus Guanajuato, Universidad de Guanajuato, Guanajuato, Gto 36050, Mexico b School of Civil Engineering and Built Environment, Queensland University of Technology (QUT), GPO Box 2434, Brisbane, Queensland, Australia cDivision of Hydrologic Sciences, Desert Research Institute, 755 E. Flamingo Road, Las Vegas, NV 89119-7363, USA dGraduate Program of Hydrologic Sciences, University of Nevada, Reno, Reno, NV 89557-0175, USA
A R T I C L E I N F O
Article history: Received 25 March 2019 Received in revised form 21 May 2019 Accepted 5 June 2019 Available online 12 June 2019
Keywords: Biochar Supported nanomaterials Environmental applications Synthesis Characterization
A B S T R A C T
Immobilizing nanomaterials in highly porous, surface active, structurally stable biochar creates novel nanocomposites that combines the well-known advantages of both materials. The exceptional contaminant adsorption and/or catalytic degradation capabilities of these nanocomposites have attracted the attention of the scientific community for possible use in environmental applications. This paper reviews the different methodologies for synthesizing biochar-supported nanomaterials, the key physical and chemical characteristics of these nanomaterials, and their performance in environmental applications, as well as identifies current knowledge gaps and potential directions for further research and development. © 2019 The Korean Society of Industrial and Engineering Chemistry. Published by Elsevier B.V. All rights
reserved.

Introduction
Biochar isahighly porous,carbon-based material producedfroma range of different feedstock biomass, usually either vegetal or animal waste, under low-oxygen conditions that has significant aromatization and anti-decomposition capabilities [1]. Biochar is reported to haveahighspecificsurfaceareaandcontainawidevarietyofnegative surface functional groups (e.g., hydroxyl, carboxyl, amino), and therefore it has gained the interest of the scientific community as a multifunctional adsorbent with diverse environmental-, agricultural-, and energy-related applications [2–4].
Fig. 1. Different methods for preparing
Enhancing the capabilities of biochar for multiple applications through the development of “engineered biochar” is a growing research field. Engineered biochar is produced using a variety of methodologies to improve the physical, chemical, and/or biological properties of the raw biomass to generate cost-effective products that overcome the main drawbacks that currently limit the broadscale application of biochar [5].
In particular, immobilizing nano-sized materials in the biochar surface is a research topic that is gaining scientific interest. Incorporating functional nanoparticles into the biochar can expand its surface area and increase its high-affinity adsorption sites, thermal stability, and/or cation exchange capacity. Wang et al. [1] recently summarized possible ways to improve incorporating nanoparticles into biochar, and other studies have outlined multiple functionalizations that significantly improves the production of engineered biochar as an adsorbent for a wide variety of trace metals [6], metalloids [7], dyes [8], and nutrients (e.g., nitrate and phosphate) [9]. These studies are in agreement with another study that found that engineered biochar with immobilized nanoparticles performed better than raw biochar without immobilized nanoparticles in all of the applications tested [10].
Using engineered biochar with immobilized nanomaterials as a sorbent in environmental remediation applications is only one of its several potential uses. Therefore, other potential uses for engineered biochar that address emerging environmental challenges should be evaluated. The purpose of this review was to assess the state-of-the-art methodologies available for producing biochar-supported nanomaterials, as well as determine the key physical and chemical characteristics and performance of these nanomaterials in environmental applications in order to identify knowledge gaps and provide recommendations for further research.
Immobilized nanomaterials in biochar
Raw biochar production involves a range of different technologies, most of which use high temperature in the absence of oxygen [11,12] to produce changes in the chemical composition and
biochar-based nanocomposites [5].
irreversible changes in the physical state of the feedstock material. The specific structural and chemical properties of raw biochar are closely related to the thermal treatment used in its production and are the parameters that influence its ability to adsorb contaminants or act as a supporting matrix for nanostructures [13–15].
Immobilizing nano-sized materials in the biochar surface were reported to help increase its surface area, active sites, thermal stability, and cation exchange capacity [1]. Several methods were reported for synthesizing immobilized nanomaterial in biochar. This paper classifies the main types of nanomaterials immobilized in biochar into the following three categories: (i) nanometal oxide/ hydroxide-biochar (N-MO/HB) composites; (ii) magnetic biochar composites; and iii) functional-nanoparticle-coated biochar [5,16,17]. These classifications are based on the type of nanomaterials used to functionalize the biochar (nanometal oxide/ hydroxide, magnetic iron oxide, and functional nanoparticles). Each type of biochar-based nanocomposite entails different synthesis methods (Fig. 1), which are discussed below.
Nanometal oxide/hydroxide-biochar composites
There are three synthesis methods reported for preparing NMO/HB composites: (a) target element enrichment by bioaccumulation (EBB); (b) pretreating biomass with metal salt (PTBMS); and (c) inserting metal oxide nanoparticles (NPs) after pyrolysis (IMONPsAP). Fig. 2 schematically illustrates these methods. In the first two methods, the metal ions are accumulated in the feedstock either by bioaccumulation or deposition, and then thermal treatment is applied to the modified biomass to convert the accumulated chemical compound to nanometal oxide/hydroxide and the impregnated biomass becomes a biochar-based nanocomposite (Fig. 2). However, bioaccumulation in the feedstock (EBB) is not used very often (Table 1) because it can contaminate
agricultural land and the crops cannot be consumed because of their resultant high metal content. The two synthetic methodologies more frequently used are PTBMS and IMONPsAP because they reduce the risk of contamination and generate nanoparticles with a more consistent size and crystalline structure [18].
The metal ions (usually as nitrogen and chloride salts) most commonly used to prepare N-MO/HB composites are Mg [19], Fe [7], Ca [20] and Al [21] because they have high stability [22–24] and low leaching characteristics [18,25]. Little research has been devoted to using organic-based or sulfur-based metal salts, even though some of them are successfully being used to synthesize nanomaterials [26,27]. Organic salts have a high basic ionization constant (pKb) (i.e., acetate pKb = 9.25), which allows high anion and cation dissociation. Therefore, they are widely used to produce nanostructures using green synthesis processes [28]. These characteristics of organic and sulfate-based metal ion salts facilitate ion attachment to biochar and improve synthesis processes. Therefore, using different organic and sulfate-based metallic salts to synthesize modified biochar is a significant area for further research.
Using electrodeposition to insert the metal ions into the biomass is an alternative for PTBMS [29,30]. Studies report that using electrodeposition not only reduces the PTBMS process time considerably (i.e., hours to minutes), but also the metal ion salt concentration required. However, this process has not been widely investigated. This highlights significant knowledge gaps in the laboratory-scale synthesis of biochar-based nanocomposites and its full-scale application because production time is a significant factor in industrial processes. If the process time can be reduced as suggested in previous studies [29,30], it would provide a significant incentive for large-scale industrial production.
Several processes are used for IMONPsAP [7,31,32], but heat treatment is the most commonly reported approach [33].

Inorganic metal salts are used as the impregnating metallic ion for all of these methods. For materials with iron and magnesium NPs, nitrogen oxides are the most commonly used because they produce the highest synthesis yield. Using organic salts to generate metal nanoparticles in other supporting materials (e.g., silica) was reported to show good synthesis yields [34,35]. Nevertheless, its use for IMONPsAP remains underexplored. This highlights a significant need for further research to assess the applicability of this approach to improve the production process.
Magnetic biochar composites
Because of their broad application, iron-based nanomaterials are of significant interest. Although they should be included in Subsection “Nanometal oxide/hydroxide-biochar composites” as nanometal oxide/hydroxide-biochar composites, we decided to create this specific subcategory to highlight their significance. Several strategies have been used (Fig. 1) to produce magnetic biochar sorbents that facilitate their separation after the treatment process [36–38]. Sorption of anionic contaminants in biochar is relatively low because the biochar surface is negatively charged [39,40]. Biochar modification using magnetic NPs to enhance the sorption of anionic contaminants [38,41] and improve conditions for synthesizing novel materials is an important area that merits

further research. The two main synthesis methods used to insert magnetic materials into biochar (Table 2) are: (i) pretreating biomass using Fe ions (PTBIIs); and (ii) chemical coprecipitation (CCP) of iron oxides on biochar [42].
The PTBIIs process involves impregnating the biomass with Fe3 +/Fe2+ followed by thermal treatment under different conditions, usually slow pyrolysis (Table 2). Other alternative thermal treatments (e.g., microwave and calcination) were reported besides slow pyrolysis [67,73–76]. Among these treatments, microwave irradiation is promising because of the short treatment time required (e.g., 10–20 min) [45,46]. Microwave technology offers a variety of opportunities for research and development because of the potential rapid synthesis of biochar-related nanomaterials at laboratory scale and larger scales. A limited number of studies have reported using calcination as an alternative thermal treatment [42] for inserting cobalt ferrites in biochar. Calcination has been reported to not require an inert environment and to be a highly feasible option for inserting ferrites in the biochar surface and generating magnetic properties in the biochar [43,47]. However, further research is needed to evaluate this possibility.
For the CCP process, magnetite (Fe3O4) is prepared in aqueous medium, and then precipitated on the biochar at pH 8 to 14 in the absence of oxygen [48]. Adding organic chelating agents or surfactants for magnetite synthesis was reported to modify the

physical properties of the final composites [49]. However, only limited studies in which modifiers (e.g., gelatin) were used to synthesize magnetic biochar are available [50], and only a few modification options have been proposed for coprecipitation treatment [51–53]. Other chelating compounds and surfactants, such as ionic liquids, were shown to be very useful for synthesizing carbon-based nanomaterials [54–58]. Because these ionic liquids have consistent and stable chemical characteristics [59], the influence of synthesis procedures on magnetic iron oxides and/or the magnetic physical properties of biochar is a significant research gap that is worth exploring. Understanding the effect of other chelating organic anions or surfactants also merits further research.
Controlling the pH values used to add cations and the Fe2+/Fe3+ ratio in CCP processes were reported to influence some physical characteristics of the magnetic nanoparticles obtained [60,61]. Sodium hydroxide was the most commonly used reagent for pH adjustment, probably because of its low cost. A few studies have used potassium hydroxide or ammonia to modify selected characteristics of magnetic biochar [47,62]. However, these studies did not compare the characteristics of the synthesized biocharcomposites with the different reagents used to control the pH of the reaction mixture. The effect of the type of reagent used to synthesize magnetic biochar is a key knowledge gap that requires exploration because of its influence on the physical characteristics of the resulting product.
Functional-nanoparticle-coated biochar
Although no widely accepted definition of a functional nanoparticle exists, we define it as a material that presents at least one dimension in the nanometer scale that has been postprocessed either chemically or physically to provide specific properties that the raw material did not exhibit. Under this premise, any metal oxide/hydroxide or magnetic nanoparticle can become a functional nanoparticle through chemical or physical modifications that provide specific, unseen properties.
Coating biochar with metallic ions is known to enhance its sorption capacity [63,64]. Coating the surface of biochar with functional nanoparticles was found to increase its capability to remove a wide variety of contaminants. This synthesis is carried out using two methods: (i) precoating the biomass with functional
nanoparticles (PCBFNPs); and (ii) impregnation of functional nanoparticles after pyrolysis (IFNPsAP) (Table 3).
The PCBFNPs process involves suspending functional nanoparticles in water to treat the biomass before pyrolysis. The nanoparticle suspension is mixed with the biomass for a specific amount of time, and then the biomass is separated and dried for later pyrolysis (Table 3). Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) are among the functional nanoparticles most frequently immobilized in biochar (see Table 3) to create an effective and recyclable sorbent for contaminant removal [65–67]. The synthesis process only requires conventional thermal treatment (i.e., slow pyrolysis) and does not require complex pretreatment [8,68]. However, the reported drawbacks of CNTs, such as high cost and inefficiencies in engineering applications, limit their use.
The functional nanoparticles most commonly used for IFNPsAP are chitosan [69,70] and zero-valent iron (ZVI) [10,71,72]. Zerovalent iron is the functional nanoparticle most reported for IFNPsAP synthesis. However, further research into the immobilization of nanoscale ZVI (nZVI) in biochar is still needed and key knowledge gaps, such as reaction yields and material characterizations and applications, still need to be investigated.
Physical and chemical characteristics of biochar-based nanomaterials
Physical characteristics
Table 4 compares the specific surface area and porosity of raw biochar of the corresponding biochar-based nanocomposite materials. It is interesting to observe how the different synthesis methods generate changes in the reported values. For example, PTBMS significantly enhances the physical characteristics (up to two orders of magnitude), which suggests that nanocomposites widen the surface of the material and that the type of feedstock influences the nature of the biochar produced and the way metals are adsorbed [73,74]. When IMONPsAP was used, not all of the materials showed an increase in porosity and/or surface area [31,75,76]. Improvements were observed using PTBIIs [100–102] and mixed results were obtained using CCP, PCBFNPs, and IFNPsAP. Using metal salts or oxides led to differing results. For example, Song et al. [33] noted a decrease in surface area and porosity (95% and 84%, respectively) after manganese oxide nanoparticles were
inserted, whereas Li et al. [73] observed an increase in surface area and porosity of over two orders of magnitude using manganese salts. The same trend was observed when iron was used either as a metal salt or metal oxide for nanocomposite production [31,74,75]. When iron salt was added to the biomass, the physical characteristics of the biochar increased significantly (almost two orders of magnitude) [74]. However, when iron oxide was added, variable results were reported [31,75]. Considering the significant effect that surface area and porosity have on the adsorption processes occurring in biochar-based nanocomposites for different applications, the lack of systematic studies on the influence of the metal species used to synthesize the composite materials is a significant knowledge gap that requires further exploration.
For magnetic N-MO/HB composites, PTBMS was found to generate an increase in surface area and porosity regardless of the feedstock used, whereas for IMONPsAP, the surface area and porosity primarily depends on the feedstock type [62]. Table 4 shows the main physical characteristics of some previously reported magnetic biochar composites. As shown, including nanoparticles increased both, the surface area and porosity in almost all cases. For example, in the case of PTBII using durian rind, the surface area improved by almost two orders of magnitude (from 10 to 890 m2g 1), whereas the porosity of the final composite increased more than two orders of magnitude (from 0.0022 to 0.722 m3g 1). However, biochar composites obtained using CCP are more often physically characterized than PTBII. The final physical characteristics of biochar obtained using CCP vary significantly based on the feedstock and the production process
used. For example, using CCP with biochar produced by gasification of oak wood or oak bark significantly reduced the surface area in both cases (from 25.4 for raw biochar to 6 and 8.8 m2g 1 for oakwood- and oak-bark-modified biochar, respectively). Fewer works reported changes in porosity and no clear trend was observed, but the same variability was noticed for the surface area. Interestingly, the reported porosity values did not necessarily follow the same trend as the surface area values. For example, using biochar produced CCP with coconut shell by pyrolysis showed a significant increase in surface area (from 30.9 to 365 m2g 1 for raw and modified biochar, respectively) and a slight decrease in porosity (from 0.042 to 0.030 m3g 1 for raw and modified biochar, respectively), which suggests that the changes observed in the surface area may be related to the characteristics of the incorporated nanomaterials rather than the increase in porosity.
Although a significant amount of information on the physical characteristics of biochar-based nanomaterials has been reported (Table 4), the chemical properties (elements and minerals found in N-MO/HB) have not been investigated to the same extent. Table 5 provides the carbon substitution by metals reported for IMONPsAP and PTBMS [77,78]. The nature of the metallic ion used was found to influence the amount of metal insertion achieved [77]. For example, in the case of manganese chloride, carbon substitution was found to be 4%, which almost doubled when the manganese salt Birnessite [(Na0.3Ca0.1K0.1)(Mn4+,Mn3+)2O4.1 5H2O] was used for IMONPsAP [33]. In the case of functionalized nanoparticles, the synthesis procedure usually only led to changes in the type of functionalized nanoparticles and not to any changes in their
physical characteristics. For example, recent studies reported [79,80] using different nanoparticles as cover for the same feedstock and found that functionalized nanoparticles defined the physical characteristics of the biochar. This is another research area that is worth exploring because if the physical characteristics of biochar can be influenced by inserting nanoparticles, then any potential issues posed by the raw material will decrease significantly by customizing the surface area and porosity of the biochar and nanoparticles.
In the case of IFNPsAP, Table 4 shows that only the immobilization of zero-valent iron is reported in literature. It is important to note that, despite the reported reduction in the surface area and porosity of the biochar, inserting nanoparticles in the biochar has advantages because of its potential use in catalysis. Using ZVI-embedded biochar as catalyst to promote advanced oxidation processes capable of eliminating contaminants in soil, water, and/or air is an important area that requires further research.
Chemical characteristics
Chemical properties of biochar-based nanocomposites have not been investigated to the same extent as raw biochar. Table 5 lists
the elements and minerals found in biochar-based nanocomposites as reported in the literature. As shown, carbon substitution by metals was reported for IMONPsAP and PTBMS [77,78] in which the nature of the metallic ion used was found to influence the amount of metal insertion achieved [77]. As reported for metal oxide/ hydroxide-biochar composites, relatively few chemical characterization were reported in the case of magnetic biochar composites (see Table 5). In this case, the nature of the synthesis method seems to be a significant influence on the amount of metal insertion achieved. For example, the impregnation yield achieved for PTBIIs in biochar made from pinewood was only 2.95%, whereas when CCP was used to insert Fe in biochar made from oak wood, oak bark, or wood, the impregnation yields achieved were 80.6, 51.3, and 24.4%, respectively. However, the lack of information prevents us from drawing conclusions and more research is required to prove this hypothesis.
Chemical properties of the final biochar composite will depend significantly on the feedstock used [70,80,81]. For example, carbon, oxygen, hydrogen, and nitrogen content in biochar was reported to increase after clay impregnation using IFNPsAP, but the process simultaneously removed almost all of the biochar minerals [80]. This could be an issue if the resulting material is to be used as a soil amendment because the minerals (nutrients) in biochar are
significant contributors to soil improvement. Table 5 also shows that potassium is lost during nanoparticle insertion using the different synthesis methods (EEB, IMONPsAP, PTBIIs, CCP, and PCBFNPs). For example, when iron was inserted by CCP in biochar produced using different oak feedstock, the material with the highest potassium loads (3.4%) generated the highest iron impregnation yield (80.6%) [81]. However, the mechanisms involved in potassium loss are unknown and further research is needed to confirm the replacement selectivity of potassium by iron (or other) nanoparticles and to characterize the mechanisms involved. This represents another knowledge gap in material synthesis because if selective insertion of nanostructures is proven, it could help generate materials with relatively high nanocomposite loads by only knowing the potassium content of the feedstock.
Performance of biochar-based nanomaterials for environmental application
Soil restoration
Using biochar for soil restoration and/or amendment has been widely reported to be highly efficient [82–84] because inorganic [85–87] and organic [88–91] contaminants are highly adsorbed and the biochar also restores nutrients [92–94], regulates bacterial activity [95–97], and maintains the soil biota [98–101]. However, little is known about using biochar-based nanocomposites for the same purpose. The interesting physical and chemical characteristics of biochar-based nanomaterials described in Section “Physical and chemical characteristics of biochar-based nanomaterials”, such as increased surface area or porosity, should significantly improve the capability of nanocomposites to remove contaminants. Biochar-based nanocomposites have properties that could be beneficial for soil restoration applications, such as allowing the dispersion and low aggregation of nanoparticles, adsorbing and/or immobilizing metal ions in the biochar or nanoparticles to form complexes or through electrostatic interaction, removing or degrading contaminants, preventing the bioavailability of by-products, and improving soil fertility [102].
Adsorption Table 6 shows the use of biochar-based nanocomposites produced by different synthesis methods (EEB, PTBIIs, and IFNPsAP) to remove inorganic contaminants (e.g., PO43 , Cr(VI)) [71,72,103]. This application is in line with the results reported in Table 4 because the biochar nanocomposites obtained using PTBIIs increased the surface area and porosity. However, the opposite was reported for IFNPsAP, and no information was available for EEB. The specific characteristics of the biochar-based nanocomposites used for inorganic contaminant adsorption in these studies was not
reported. In all of these cases, the performance of the biocharbased nanocomposites was reported to be significantly higher than the performance reported for raw biochar. For example, ZVI nanoparticles immobilized in rape straw biochar by PTBMS removed 100% of Cr(VI) in contaminated soil, whereas raw biochar from poultry manure removed only 21%.
A potentially interesting application of biochar-based nanocomposites for soil restoration is the removal of pollutants that can later be used as fertilizer, such as phosphates (PO43 ) [104,105]. Removing PO43 from a contaminated water body and releasing it into the field as fertilizer has been done using alginate- and chitosan-based materials. Only a limited number of studies on the removal of nitrogen-based pollutants (e.g., ammonium and nitrate) using biochar-based nanocomposites are available, which highlights another area for future research [74,106].
Limited attention has been given to using biochar-based nanocomposites for the adsorption of organic pollutants in soil [107]. It would be expected that the changes in element content displayed in Table 5 would lead to changes in the functional groups on the surface of the biochar after the addition of nanoparticles, which may attract ionic species and polarized and/or nonpolarized organic structures over time, as previously proposed [108]. For example, using Ni/Fe biochar in the adsorption of polybrominated diphenyl esters (PBDEs) was reported previously and it not only reduces phytotoxicity, but also reduces the accumulation and translocation of PBDEs in the soil-plant system [109]. Wang et al. [110] recently compiled a review devoted to the application of biochar-supported nZVI (nZVI/BC) for contaminant removal from soil and water in which they discuss the removal of heavy metals, nitrates, and organic compounds using nZVI/BC. They concluded that the nanocomposite can attenuate the contaminants in its surface and enhance electron transfer from nZVI to the target contaminants.
The major mechanisms involved in the adsorption process of biochar-based nanocomposites are ion exchange, physical adsorption, electrostatic interaction, and complexation. Ion exchange is expected when functional groups in the surface ionize at low pH values and surface ions (e.g., Na+, K+, and Ca2+) are exchanged with heavy metal ions or cationic organic pollutants [111]. Physical adsorption is when the surface characteristics (i.e., surface area and porosity) are used to adsorb metallic ions and/or organic substances in micropores, and it is closely related to the pollutant concentration and temperature during the process. Electrostatic interaction is usually observed when pH is greater than the point of zero charge (pHpzc) of the nanocomposite, and the negative charge on the surface is usually generated by oxygen-containing functional groups that cause the attachment of positively charged metallic ions. Finally, complexation is usually associated with the interaction of oxygen-containing functional groups and positively charged metallic ions to form complexes [112].

Catalysis Wu et al. [102] synthesized nanoparticles of Ni/Fe by IMONPsAP in biochar and used them to degrade polybrominated diphenyl ethers (PBDEs) from electronic waste (e-waste). They followed its degradation and monitored the formation of bromide ions in the system over time, and found that Ni/Fe bimetallic nanoparticles removed BDE from soil. Other authors have reported using magnetic biochar composites to catalyze sodium persulfate for the remediation of sediments contaminated with polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) [113]. They found that the magnetic biochar composite is an efficient catalyst for removing high-ring PAHs as opposed to low-ring PAHs, and they suggested this was because of the affinity of high-ring PAHs to the biochar surface. This is particularly interesting because of the selectivity of the biochar-based nanocomposite for some of the structures included in the PAHs group, which may present possibilities for other potential applications. Despite these encouraging results, using biochar-based nanocomposites as catalysts for the degradation of organic contaminants in soil is not well understood. We believe this lack of information is another knowledge gap that is worth exploring because biochar-nanocomposites are highly cost-efficient catalysts that outperform using biochar and nanoparticles separately, enhance soil adsorption capacity for organic pollutants, reduce desorption and bioavailability, and improve the physical and chemical properties of soil [107].
In the case of using biochar-based nanocomposites as a catalyst, the main mechanism reported is related with advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) and involves generating free radicals (either oxygen- or sulfur-based), which are the transient chemical species responsible for the cleavage of chemical bonds and structural degradation [4,114]. Some of the nanoparticles reported to be immobilized in biochar react with water, or oxygen molecules, and oxidants (e.g., hydrogen peroxide, persulfate, peroxymonosulfate) to produce free radicals at a high rate that completely degrades organic pollutants independently of the phase (i.e., liquid or solid) of application [34,108].
Wastewater reclamation
The benefits of using biochar in wastewater treatment have already been established [5,115,116]. The primary use of biocharbased nanocomposites has been in phase change (adsorption) water treatment processes. However, some recent studies reported
using these nanocomposites as catalysts for advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) [5,16]. The main research areas and knowledge gaps related to biochar-based nanocomposites are discussed below.
Adsorption Table 7 lists the reported applications of biochar-based nanocomposites to remove inorganic contaminants. As shown, PO43 is the most widely reported inorganic contaminant removed using biochar-based nanocomposites [29,30,75]. Based on the information in Table 7, it appears that phosphates can be removed using biochar-based nanocomposites produced by any of the different synthesis methods reported (PRBMS, IMONPsAP, CCP, or IFNPsAP) and that introducing Mg nanoparticles seems to produce the best results [117]. When nanocomposites such as chitosan and alginate were added to the biochar by IFNPsAP, PO43 removal barely reached 70% for surface water and did not even reach 10% for wastewater effluent [134]. When Mg nanoparticles immobilized by IFNPsAP were used, PO43 removal reached at least 70% regardless of the water source [117] or the biochar material used [21,29,30,75,117]. Only two metals (Mg and Fe) have been used to produce biochar-based nanocomposites and tested for the removal of nitrogen-based nutrients. The composites generated through PTBMS synthesis were reported to have low removal for ammonium (50%) and nitrates (35%) when Mg and Fe nanoparticles immobilized in biochar were used, respectively [74,106]. Therefore, further research is needed on the removal of nitrogenbased contaminants using biochar-based nanocomposites and the synthesis methods used for their production.
Some recent studies suggest that biochar-based nanocomposites interact selectively with phosphate and ammonium. For example, when both phosphate and ammonium are present in complex solutions, phosphate was reported to be preferentially adsorbed by biochar with immobilized MgO nanoparticles produced from sugarcane residues by PTBMS [106]. Nevertheless, significantly lower PO43 removal (10–70%) was achieved using biochar from orange peel with immobilized Fe nanoparticles using CCP [41]. The reasons for the different results were not discussed. The potential selectivity of biochar-based nanocomposites for specific contaminants is another significant knowledge gap that merits further investigation because understanding these selective adsorption processes would lead to the development of materials customized to remove specific ions from water. removal efficiency of heavy metals (mainly Cr(VI), Cd(II), and Pb (II)) in water using biochar-based nanocomposites. As shown, the different feedstock materials and synthesis methods used for biochar production [62] produced a range of removal rates. Reddy and Lee [42] reported synthesizing cobalt ferrite biochar using PTBIIs, which showed a decreased influence of pH on the metal removal process, but very few studies have investigated this phenomenon. Confirming this decreased variability in metal removal using a second metal in addition to magnetite embedded in the biochar would be an important area for
further research. The synergy between magnetic biochar-based nanocomposites was also observed in the removal of arsenic from water [50,63]. These studies found that using a polymer (gelatin) in addition to iron nanoparticles immobilized by CCP in chestnut-shell-based biochar completely removed. As by using two orders of magnitude less Fe/gelatin biochar-composite material (0.4 g L 1) than when immobilized iron nanoparticles were tested alone (5 g L 1). Immobilizing more than one nanocomposite in the biochar is another important direction for further research.
Catalysis Table 9 shows the removal efficiency of different contaminants using biochar-based nanocomposites for catalytic applications. Very limited information is currently available for this use of biochar-based nanocomposites. Only one type of material (i.e., nZVI) and one type of synthesis method (i.e., IFNPsAP) have been used so far to produce the biochar-based nanocomposites. Using nanocomposites to produce free radicals in catalytic treatments through the reaction of ZVI with water or catalytic persulfate decomposition are the only mechanisms suggested. Therefore, further research is needed on using oxidants such as peroxymonosulfate, hydrogen peroxide, or percarbonate (Na2CO3 1.5H2O2) and nanocomposites such as metal-ferrites, cobalt, or copper to generate hydroxyl- or sulfate-based processes for water treatment.
Carbon sequestration
As shown in Table 10, despite the limited information available, existing studies on CO2 capture using biochar-based nanocomposites show high efficiency [153–160]. Synthesizing biochar-based nanocomposites with Al, Fe, and Mg using PTBMS showed that Al generated the highest CO2 capture (71 mg of CO2 per gram of biochar), which wasalmost twofoldthe results obtainedusing Fe and Mg [118]. Creamer et al. [121] used MgO nanoparticles stabilized in the biochar structure to generate up to 235 mg g 1 capture of CO2 after 3 h. These researchers found that the biomass: nanoparticles ratio significantly affected the capability of the nanocomposite to sequester carbon dioxide. Plaza et al. [122] found that although biochar-based nanocomposites demonstrated good CO2 capture, it was less than half of the results obtained using biochar alone. The relatively better performance of raw biochar suggests that an important line of research exist, mainly the variety of biochar-based nanocomposites that have not been tested as yet. It is hypothesized that it ispossibleto develop selective biochar-based nanocomposites for CO2 capture using the diverse synthesis methods previously reported. The potential applications for decreasing pollutant emissions in the atmosphere may go beyond industrial use if the developed nanocomposites are also used to reduce CO2 released by mobile sources. However, the lack of information on this topic highlights another significant knowledge gap.
Conclusions
Based on the critical review of the literature, applications of engineered biochar have increased in recent years. However, significant knowledge gaps exist that highlight the current challenges in technical understanding and cost-effective production of using engineered biochar for environmental applications.
The key knowledge gaps identified are:
1 Several different ways to generate biochar-based nanocomposites were reported in the literature and various results were described depending on a significant number of variables. The main knowledge gap is a method to control the characteristics of the engineered materials being produced and tailoring their specific performance to the synthesis conditions and/or identifying the most cost-effective use for the engineered materials. 2 The relatively successful use of plain biochar for soil amendment/restoration, water reclamation, or CO2 capture has been reported in the past. However, little known about the use of biochar-based nanocomposites for the same environmental applications. 3 Some novel technologies to produce cost-effective, biocharbased nanocomposites have been proposed with promising
results. However, there is relatively limited information on the influential parameters and the treatment conditions required. 4 The capability of biochar-based nanocomposites to remove nutrients from eutrophic water bodies that can then be used as soil amendments has significant environmental value, but only limited information on this possible use is currently available. 5 Although different biochar-based nanocomposites were successfully tested to adsorb contaminants during water treatment processes, their use as a catalyst remains limited to one type of material and synthesis methodology. 6 Raw biochar was tested for CO2 capture and found to have high efficiency. However, using biochar-based nanocomposites did not report good results compared with raw biochar. Therefore, this merits further exploration.

metadata.abstractText: Immobilizing nanomaterials in highly porous, surface active, structurally stable biochar creates novel nanocomposites that combines the well-known advantages of both materials. The exceptional contaminant adsorption and/or catalytic degradation capabilities of these nanocomposites have attracted the attention of the scientific community for possible use in environmental applications. This paper reviews the different methodologies for synthesizing biochar-supported nanomaterials, the key physical and chemical characteristics of these nanomaterials, and their performance in environmental applications, as well as identifies current knowledge gaps and potential directions for further research and development. © 2019 The Korean Society of Industrial and Engineering Chemistry.
